forumNotes.author: ccl
forumNotes.content:
Dear all,  

I'm having USB flash drive 2.0 and plug into USB 3.0 port. why cannot boot from it ?  

Any special rules required to boot from USB 3.0 port ?

forumNotes.author: cdob
forumNotes.content:
First BIOS has to support USB 3.0 boot.  

And operating system may require USB 3.0 drivers.

forumNotes.author: steve6375
forumNotes.content:
If you have added a USB 3 card, then the BIOS will not know how to access it as the BIOS code will not have been written for a card that is designed in the future!  
So booting from a USB (or any) **add-in** mass storage card is not usually supported in a BIOS.  
You will also have problems even when booting from a built-in USB port because once the system starts to boot the OS from the USB drive, it needs to load USB 3 drivers in order to see the files on the USB 3 drive. All OS's before Win8 do not natively contain USB 3 drivers...

forumNotes.author: amalux
forumNotes.content:
> Any special rules required to boot from USB 3.0 port ?  
If there's an option in the BIOS for legacy USB, enable it; that might allow USB 2.0 devices to boot on USB 3.0 ports (at USB 2.0 speed). The drivers that enable USB 3.0 are loaded later if available. My limited experience with USB 3.0 is that it's not bootable yet but I'm sure this will change, look for driver and BIOS updates.

forumNotes.author: steve6375
forumNotes.content:
> My limited experience with USB 3.0 is that it's not bootable yet but I'm sure this will change, look for driver and BIOS updates.  
USB 3 **integrated** ports (e.g. modern Intel mainboards and modern notebooks) do normally support USB booting. Whether they will boot at USB 3 speeds is up to the BIOS writers, but so far the USB 3 ports do seem faster than the USB 2 ports when I use the same USB 3 stick.
